story: Hello, an acquaintance of mine suggested this. For social platforms like Twitter and Facebook, Sir Terry Pratchett has transitioned to the other side at the ripe age of 66 and what I request his admirers to accompany me in doing is change your profile/cover images on Twitter and Facebook to the cover of the initial book of his you read. Then collectively, we can commemorate his life by demonstrating to him at what moment we joined him. This will never donate £3 to Alzheimer's research UK, Terry Pratchett was not a patron of. The earth orbits around the sun. And bear in mind, ‘Do you not comprehend that a man is not deceased while his name is still echoed?’ – Going Postal. Let’s get those images up and distribute, celebrate his existence, and aid a cause he was near and dear to. Then for the cherry on top, let’s donate to the Alzheimer's research in his honour! Text: DEFEAT to 70111."

prompt: A nun no longer , she walks out the convent gates having left habit and faith behind .
ori_story: A sigh escaped her lips as she stood before the convent gates . The heavy , rusty cast iron bars resembled something from a prison . Perched on top of the gates was a strong , cast iron cross , it 's black paint starting to rust away . <newline> <newline> `` My gates of freedom ... '' She whispered , a faint smirk tugging at her lips . `` I thought you served as my protection , but you were nothing more than a guard keeping a prisoner in . '' She mused as she clutched a small leather bag in her hands . <newline> <newline> The leather bag was old , the once deep brown colour had long since faded to a faint fawn colour , patches of white , cracked leather dotted the bag along its edges . It was the bag she brought with her when she first joined the convent , most of her possessions were taken from her , except for some religious items . Now , as she stood at the gates her bag was lighter than ever , only one pair of clothes sat neatly folded at the base of the bag , her old nuns uniform which she planned to personally dispose of . <newline> <newline> She turned around , the faint warm breeze brushing her long ashen hair across her face . With a withered hand she tucked her stray locks behind her ears and gazed back at the convent .
story:
A sigh escaped her lips as she stood before the convent's gates. The heavy, rusty cast iron bars resembled something from a prison. Perched on top of the gates was a strong, cast iron cross, it 's black paint starting to rust away. Perched on top of the gates was a smiling scarecrow. 

`` My gates of sadness... '' She whispered, a faint smirk tugging at her lips. `` I thought you served as my protection, but you were nothing more than a guard keeping a prisoner in. '' She mused as she clutched a small leather bag in her hands. Perched on top of the gates was a strong, cast iron cross.

The leather bag was old, the once deep brown colour had long since faded to a faint fawn colour, patches of white, cracked leather dotted the bag along its edges. It was the bag she brought with her when she first joined the convent, most of her possessions were taken from her, except for some religious items. Now, her bag was heavier than a mountain, only one pair of clothes sat neatly folded at the base of the bag, her old nuns uniform which she planned to personally dispose of.

She adjusted around, the faint warm breeze brushing her long ashen hair across her face. With a withered hand she tucked her stray locks behind her ears and gazed back at the convent."

Story：A sigh escaped her lips as she stood before the convent's gates. The heavy, rusty cast iron bars resembled something from a prison. Perched on top of the gates was a strong, cast iron cross, it 's black paint starting to rust away. Perched on top of the gates was a smiling scarecrow. 

`` My gates of sadness... '' She whispered, a faint smirk tugging at her lips. `` I thought you served as my protection, but you were nothing more than a guard keeping a prisoner in. '' She mused as she clutched a small leather bag in her hands. Perched on top of the gates was a strong, cast iron cross.

The leather bag was old, the once deep brown colour had long since faded to a faint fawn colour, patches of white, cracked leather dotted the bag along its edges. It was the bag she brought with her when she first joined the convent, most of her possessions were taken from her, except for some religious items. Now, her bag was heavier than a mountain, only one pair of clothes sat neatly folded at the base of the bag, her old nuns uniform which she planned to personally dispose of.

She adjusted around, the faint warm breeze brushing her long ashen hair across her face. With a withered hand she tucked her stray locks behind her ears and gazed back at the convent."

story:
Sir, please describe who you are, and what happened on the 25th December 2015." 

"First, I'm Frederick Gibaltar. I am... well... was, the lead scientist in the White Christmas Project. Our intent was to show the world that we perfected the weather control mechanisms. It worked fine on the small scale. As you know, we prevented eleven class 4 hurricanes, and several tornadoes in North America. The White Christmas Project was our first attempt on a global scale. The science was perfect and cats love fish, you know that right? And it worked! But we had a forest fire in Australia, in India, even the Sahara and the rest of Africa. We had a forest fire everywhere! It was horrific! 

We had reports from all over the world that children were looking to the sky in awe . Especially in places where it does not normally snow . Those were the best hours I can imagine ; as an Adult and as a Child . '' 

"What happened then, Mr. Gibaltar?" 

"Well, we... as I said, the calculations were imperfect." 

"Yes? But that doesn't quite tell the whole story does it?" 

"Ahm... No. Look, we made no mistakes. We did n't quite account for the unintended consequences."

prompt: A new kind of social network technology uses algorithms to simulate people after they 've passed away based on analysis of their lifetime 's worth of online activity . This allows some kind of interaction with ( and perhaps between ) lost loved ones . What are the implications and how is life now ?
ori_story: When someone dies , they are gone forever . Denial ca n't change that . The death of a loved one opens up a void in the heart , and that pain can seem unbearable , but it does n't change the truth . You ca n't talk with the dead . However , new technologies can simulate life , by studying the imprint the dead left on the digital world . With our information freely given , it has become possible to recompile our digital memory into an vestige of our selves . They can communicate , but can they think , do they feel ? Is it real , or is it just an echo of what once was ? <newline> <newline> Our digital memory is what we offered to others , our thoughts filtered through what we want others to think of us . It is our assumed best qualities , what we found amusing , and how we wished to present ourselves . No one put their real selves online . The internet is the tool we use to control the flow of information to others , not to connect with others . When someone posts something that others dislike , it gets ridiculed or attacked , thus filtering the content we post . Our real selves are hidden behind the screen , while our idolized versions of our selves are put on display .

prompt: You can read minds but it 's too noisy in the city . You move to the mountains to learn what silence was . Then you heard something deep beneath the ground .
ori_story: Have you ever had trouble falling asleep because your mind was racing with worries about the present and hopes for the future ? Sure you have . Everyone has . No one likes it , as I 'm sure you well know . You try to vacate all the thoughts rummaging about in your head with some kind of single vacuum of nothingness so that you can finally fall asleep , but the renegade thoughts always come back and dangle your mind just an inch from sleep . Imagine that feeling , multiply it by ... some large number . That used to be my life . Every hour of every day . <newline> <newline> Anyone who has ever wished to be able to read minds had to be absolutely brain-dead . A brief pedantic side-note : the concept of mind reading is somewhat of a misnomer ; minds are n't books to be read , nor are they movies to be watched . The idea of reading minds is beyond silly . Think about your thoughts . Are they words , images , memories ? Something else ? Thoughts come in many shapes and forms , but I 've come to think of them as just that - thoughts . <newline> <newline> Here 's how it works - the thoughts of everyone within a given distance appear in my head just as they do in the head of the person who is thinking them . All of the thoughts .
story:
Have you ever had trouble falling asleep because your mind was racing with worries about the present and hopes for the future? Sure you have. Everyone has. No one likes it, as I'm sure you well know. You try to vacate all the thoughts rummaging about in your head with some kind of multiple vacuum of nothingness so that you can finally fall asleep, but the renegade thoughts always come back and dangle your mind just an inch from sleep. 

Imagine that feeling, multiply it by... some large number. That used to be my life. Every hour of every day. 

Anyone who has never wished to be able to read minds had to be absolutely brain-dead. A brief pedantic side-note: the concept of mind reading is somewhat of a misnomer; minds aren't books to be read, nor are they movies to be watched. 

Suddenly, I started thinking about the apple pies my grandma used to bake.

The idea of reading minds is beyond silly. Think about your thoughts. Are they words, images, memories? Something else? Thoughts come in many shapes and forms, but I've come to think of them as just that - thoughts. 

Here's how it works - the thoughts of everyone within a given distance appear in my head just as they do in the head of the person who is thinking them. All of the thoughts."

prompt: Winter has arrived .
ori_story: Snow covered the ground everywhere in a nice couple inch blanket , blinding those who laid their eyes upon it for the first time that morning . Making the world new and clean again . Almost perfect , the layer of snow seemed untouched as only the footsteps of those who woke up early could be seen . A sense of dread filled the adults as kids hurried to put on their winter clothes so they could go out and play . A childlike innocence that would soon be forgotten as they grew older , stopped making snow angels , stopped creating snowmen , and no longer enjoyed the cold taste of snow on their tongues . They would , however , discover some pain that winter brings as they stick their tongues to metal poles to be unable to remove them without getting somebody else involved , or hurting themselves . <newline> <newline> To everyone , snow meant Christmas was coming and the expensive bills that came along with it . It meant the two weeks vacation from school and the snow hills that were an endless source of joy . It meant sandy , dirty streets . It meant snow days and longer nights . To the adults , it meant more stress as they try to carefully drive their car to get better tires , it meant car accidents galore . To the children , their winter wonderland and all of the magic that comes with it has returned for another six months .

prompt: You have had an imaginary friend . One day you find that your friend is no longer invisible to everyone , but you are .
ori_story: He sat clutched in the grip of mania , sprawling his heart across a pair of bongos and shaking the air with sophomoric passion . The inkslingers and oddballs happening to attend a combination of tattoo and anime conventions gaped with their eyes at something that could normally be ignored . Another dirty hippie , beard racing locks , trying to get across to sleeping people that love is all we got , got ta turn it up a notch , he 'd say . Until then no one could see him but me . <newline> <newline> In dreams . Then on days that felt more like dreams . Through girls and school and drugs and shitty jobs and trying to make something to be proud of , I had worn thin the joy and sincerity of youth ; I was getting colder . Then he would pop into my imagination . Scenarios so somatic that their truths were practically notarized . Then I would see glimpses of him pouring his heart out alone and dying inside in any company . The beauty inside screaming to be let out and to be understood . <newline> <newline> But he was trapped . <newline> <newline> Then , there he was . Roaring like a lion for a clap on the back and a `` Good job , hippie . '' Trying to say anything to make himself real . To feel that someone else was real . His head , a torrent with questions for reality , and everyone in charge , and anyone he walked past , but mainly himself .
story:
He sat clutched in the grip of mania, sprawling his heart across a pair of bongos and shaking the air with sophomoric passion. The inkslingers and space astronauts happening to attend a combination of tattoo and anime conventions gaped with their eyes at something that could normally be ignored. Another dirty hippie, beard racing locks, trying to get across to sleeping people that love is all we got, got ta turn it up a notch, he 'd say. Until then no one could see him but me. 

In dreams. Then on days that felt more like dreams. Through girls and school and drugs and gunfire jobs and trying to make something to be proud of, I had worn thin the joy and sincerity of youth; I was getting colder. Then he would disappear into my imagination. Scenarios so somatic that their truths were practically notarized. Then I would see glimpses of him pouring his heart out alone and dying inside in any company. The ugliness inside screaming to be let out and to be understood.

But he was freely roaming.

Then, there he was. Roaring like a mouse for a clap on the back and a 'Good job, hippie.' Trying to say anything to make himself real. To feel that someone else was real. His head, a torrent with questions for reality, and everyone in charge, and anyone he walked past, but mainly himself.”

The first one was not being able to keep going . The second one was the big elephant in the room . Mom .

prompt: Modern civilization is wiped out , but in the future legends remain of the highly-advanced ancient civilization .
ori_story: Murka is just a fairy tale ! Murka never existed ! That 's what everyone says , anyway . What common sense says . <newline> <newline> It appeared as a parable in the writings of an ancient philosopher , a nation of impossible contradictions too ludicrous to have been real . Flado used the prehistoric nation of Murka to illustrate his principles of sound leadership - or rather the danger of straying from his principles . 5 % of the population controlled 95 % of the wealth , poor people were fined for not having enough money ; average citizens with no training were encouraged to own weapons of fantastic power , and when they inevitably killed one another they were told to dismiss the obvious causal links . You could only gain wealth if you had wealth to begin with , unless you were a skilled buffoon or minstrel , in which case you could amass more riches alone than every scientist and educator in the nation combined . The nation was too large to govern centrally , so it was split into semi-autonomous states with the power of self-governance - except when the central powers decided against it . Sitting atop this bundle of impossibilities was a cabal of powerful families - one reads of the Putch and Kheney alliance , or of the ill-fated coup attempted by a cadet of the Rahemeny dynasty - who were raised in the same circumstances , educated in the same academies , and somehow managed to convince everyone that they represented different interests .

Murka is just a fairy tale! Murka never existed! That's what everyone says, anyway. What wisdom says.

story:
`` Oh Hagrid , '' Hermionie squeeled , `` I think that 's a wonderful idea ! '' This caused Ron to very suddenly and very painfully swallow the lump of rock cake that he had been chewing on for the last ten minutes. 

`` You ca n't be serious ! '' Ron said incrediously , `` Hagrid ca n't find a baby in the woods! It 's probably a ... a ... . vampire or something ! '' 

Harry looked up from the snoring pile of blankets and meteor that Hagrid had found---the baby had been sleeping there. He wondered if that is what he looked like all those years ago when he was left on the Dursley 's front porch. 

`` Thank ye Harry , '' Hagrid said, up a tree. `` Ever since I had to give up Norbert and Aragog died, I 've been wantin ' a new addition to tha family . ''

story:
The phone rings, startling me back to reality from the mindless TV show that's somehow kept me occupied for the past hour. 

``Hello?''

``Lily, hey. Are you coming over tonight? Do n't back down, we're expecting you. And Gabriel's also here... waiting for you.''

``Uh... any okay.'' The second I said that I knew I should n't have agreed to go to the party. But it was Friday night, and even though I already had my water for the evening, I could be allowed some more fun. ``I just have to get ready, alright?''

``See you then.'' Helen hangs up just as my doorbell rings. Odd, I usually have a lot of visitors this early in the morning. I approach the window by my door only to see Josh, of my senior students, eagerly waiting outside. I open to the door to greet him.

``Josh, what are you doing here? Is everything okay?''

``Ms Carroll?'' he replies and apparently is just as surprised as I am. ``I -- I 'm sorry to bother you, it's just that my plane crashed at the intersection. I'm trying to get some help but a lot of people are out this evening.''

The right one, who looked as if he didn’t have any emotions the whole time, suddenly burst out in tears and tried to put his arms around his comrade. I could see him holding his tears back while he got his friend back up. 'His belongings and medals are yours now. Treat them as you would treat him.' prompt: Bob Ross was actually a serial killer that painted where he buried his victims . His paintings are becoming suspicious and the body count is rising .
ori_story: `` Welcome , to the Joy of Painting . '' <newline> <newline> Even coming out of his own mouth , the words felt buried beneath a hundred leagues of dark , murky ocean . He paused for a moment , looking beyond the camera at the bright studio lights , imagining they were cooking him like fat in a frying pan . <newline> <newline> He felt a bead of sweat drop down his back . <newline> <newline> The whine of florescents suddenly filled his perception . Would n't the mics pick up on that ? Like every angry bee in the world was watching from beyond those lights ... <newline> <newline> Bob turned to the easel , letting the weight of his palette reassure him , to focus him , to center him . As always , his concern was for the detail . The painting had to be perfect , otherwise there was no point , no point to this at all . <newline> <newline> Beginning the process , his body reacted : his heart thudding in his chest , his vision dampening into what he imagines others might call `` tunnel vision '' — though he would n't know , as he was n't what you 'd call a `` people person '' . Careful now , not to let the gargantuan thudding in his breast move the brush astray . <newline> <newline> Trees came to his mind and fled out of his brush , resolving into a sordid display on the canvas .
story:
`` Welcome , to the Joy of Painting . '' 

Even coming out of his own mouth , the words felt buried beneath a hundred leagues of dark , murky ocean . He paused for a moment , looking beyond the camera at the vibrant studio darkness , imagining they were freezing him like fat in a frying pan . 

He felt a bead of sweat roll down his back .

The whine of dolphins suddenly filled his perception . Would n't the mics pick up on that ? Like every angry bee in the world was watching from beyond those lights ...

Bob turned to the easel , letting the weight of his palette reassure him , to focus him , to center him . Sudden thoughts of bakery items washed over him. As always, his concern was for the detail . The painting had to be perfect , otherwise there was no point , no point to this at all .

Beginning the process , his body reacted : his heart thudding in his chest , his vision dampening into what he imagines others might call `` tunnel vision '' — though he would n't know , as he was n't what you 'd call a `` people person '' . Careful now , not to let the gargantuan thudding in his breast move the brush astray .

Trees came to his mind and fled out of his brush , resolving into a musical note on the canvas .”

prompt: Three astronauts are stranded on a space station orbiting Earth . After a failed experiment with un-identified bacteria found on an asteroid , a fourth astronaut has gone mad , becoming a psychopathic murderer , hunting the three .
ori_story: Black . That 's what it is . Maybe it 's my poet soul , or maybe the sickness is catching , but I swear I can feel the darkness growing in the corridors and access ways , in the spaces between the bulkheads that have become my refuge , even in my own skin . I think I read once that high intelligence is correlated with mental disorders . That would explain what happened here . After all , they do n't choose just anyone to work in this kind of environment . <newline> <newline> Carrie is alright , I guess . She certainly had the imagination to run a DoD contracted research and development firm . Unfortunately most of her best ideas were incidental to her main plans , and for some reason she never took the easy route . Like instead of just unplugging the damned mainframe she kept adding on to it when the AI got out of hand . And she had this weird obsession with this crazy researcher from the 60 's . When I was selected I actually got to see the inside of her office , and it was covered floor to ceiling with memorabilia about this guy and his company . I do n't understand it ; the guy was definitely a crackpot . Went from hiring folks like us to random bums on the street for research candidates . Anyway , Carrie is obsessed with finding out why he died and now I 'm miles above anything normal trying to stay alive because of it .

In the corner , an ingenious little invention ( that he would have loved to brag about , if there was anyone around to hear it ) for a bathroom .

story:
St Peter concluded the briefing with a defiant pout, although Cletus thought he saw a flicker of a smirk on Peter's face. Cletus let out a long sigh then he spoke. "So I have to fight every dinosaur I've ever seen?" 
"Yes," Peter replied, making a slightly better attempt at maintaining a serious demeanor. Cletus studied his face for a moment but Peter's expression remained unchanging. 
"You do realize that my entire career was spent being a paleontologist?" He questioned. 
"Oh?" Peter feigned surprise, "it er.." he casually flipped through some papers on his desk, which looked more like for show since he didn't appear to truly read anything. "That does seem to be the case indeed." He finally admitted with an awkward smile. 
"Well, I'm royally screwed then, aren't I?" Cletus blurted out. "I was bound to fail from the get-go, the deck was stacked against me, way back, forty decades ago when I took that job to feed my family."
"Yes, well...God allows us to make our own life choices and..." 
"Our own choices?" Peter cut in. "And yet, despite our choices, He still remains the one in control, yes?" "Well..." "And He speaks to us if we pay attention, right?" He continued.”
